entry.title: Re: User ID for IAS users
entry.content:
Hello @dyaryura  Hello @MatthiasL 

Thanks again for the helpful discussions!

I still need some clarification on the technical setup of Global User ID  for example SAC especially how it works with IPS and SSO

We provision users from Entra ID ‚Üí IAS ‚Üí SAC. The Global User ID is automatically created and assigned to each user in IAS.

I'm not exactly sure how to implement this Global User ID in a Cloud Application. I have two main ideas (options) and need help deciding which is the correct and recommended way.

Option 1: UUID in a Custom SAC Attribute, SSO via Custom SAML Mapping

  • User Provisioning ( Target System - SAC)

              The Global User ID ($['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap:2.0:User']['userUuid']) is provisioned into a custom attribute in SAC. For example:

  

{

 "sourcePath": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap:2.0:User']['userUuid']",

  "optional": true,

  "targetPath": "$.attributes.customGlobalUserID"

}

The custom attribute ‚ÄûcustomGlobalUserID‚Äú will be created in SAC.

  • SAC SSO Setup:
    • In SAC for "User Attribute to map to your identity provider," I select "Custom SAML User Mapping  and choose  the attribute ‚ÄûcustomGlobalUserID‚Äú
    • The "USER ID" field in SAC would be filled with the "Login Name"  Value from IAS (e.g., testname).

 

Option 2: GUID Directly into SAC's "USER ID" Field, SSO via USER ID Mapping

  • User Provisioning (Target System - SAC):

                       The Global User ID ($['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap:2.0:User']['userUuid']) is provisioned directly into "USER ID" field in SAC. For example:

  {

  "sourcePath": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap:2.0:User']['userUuid']",

  "targetPath": "$['urn:sap:params:scim:schemas:extension:sac:2.0:user-custom-parameters']['userName']"

}

 

  • SAC SSO Setup:
    • For "User Attribute to map to your identity provider," I will select "USER ID."

 

I haven't fully understood the implementation yet and would really appreciate your help.

Thank you in advance!!!

Best regards

entry.title: Unavailability of Released CDS view for Warehouse task - Internal moment
entry.content:
Requirement - Pack outbound delivery - HU Based - GI Label trigger with left over stock

We are printing the GI label with reference to the Outbound delivery number from SAP to 3rd Party system while using the App Pack outbound deliveries with reference to the Outbound delivery number. It is a Warehouse task and getting confirmed, but the warehouse task details do not contain the reference document of the Outbound delivery number in any CDS Views or SAP standard tables.

However, we found the SAP standard CDS view "I_EWM_handlingunititem", which contains the Outbound Delivery details. But this is not yet released in the 2508 version.  

Technical Design: We are using an event-based triggering process for the above requirement. Below is the Event used for Warehouse Internal moment(Leftover Stock) Labels.

Event - sap/s4/beh/WarehouseOrder/TaskConfirmed/v1

Once the packing is done in the app "Pack Outbound Delivery", the Warehouse Task event gets triggered. Based on the Warehouse task, we need to obtain all the required details from the Outbound Delivery. So the challenge is that we don't have a released CDS View(I_EWM_handlingunititem) to find the Outbound delivery number linkage from packed outbound delivery warehouse task details. We need a workaround solution as this requirement is crucial for the Business to operate and print the labels in the warehouse.

entry.title: Has Devtoberfest just proved that ABAP is in fact dead?
entry.content:
I'm sorry to say SAP, Devtoberfest: You have lost me.

You say Monday is for ABAP, but in my book table/view entities, annotations, projections, service definitions, service bindings, analytics, joule etc. is not really ABAP. 

A few years ago Thursday was for analytics and AI, but today I saw an "ABAP" session about "Explore the Latest Updates in ABAP CDS". You call it "ABAP" CDS, but this session contained stuff like joule and analytics (used to be Thursday stuff) - i didn't see one single real ABAP command. 

And it is the same for all ABAP Sessions. So far I would say that 80% of the Monday stuff does not belong in my ABAP book. The only session I really could relate to so far was " Custom code development and transformation for Clean Core in SAP S/4HANA".

Now you even put ABAP as a minor part in a corner of Build. As an ABAP developer that really makes me feel devaluated.

Of course you have all the right in the world to use your brands as you like and rebrand when you like,  but I don't really understand what you want to achieve by calling CDS views for ABAP CDS and say RAP is ABAP when it is not really? 

Someone will probably argue that the new declarative annotation language is embedded in ABAP (the cloud version), but does that make it ABAP? It somehow reminds me of the Tower of Babel.

Best Regards
Thomas Madsen Nielsen

entry.title: Re: User ID for IAS users
entry.content:
Hi @tskwin 

I configured this recently for a SAC tenant with Global user D but i'm not using IPS provisioning,

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ANALYTICS_CLOUD/00f68c2e08b941f081002fd3691d86a7/a6b66dfa878b4ea7a539a7ef8e73db74.html

As part of the SSO config I've set up the "Subject name identifier" of the app in IAS to be the Global User ID and used the "Custom SAML User Mapping" in the SAC side as described in the documentation. You can pass also Groups as part of the SAML assertion to grant users permissions and also enable "Shadow User Creation".

If tou want to provision with IPS i don't see a specific atribute for Global User ID like in other transformations, but you'll need to map the idPUserID atribute as described in https://help.sap.com/docs/identity-provisioning/identity-provisioning/target-sap-analytics-cloud

entry.title: Using First Name and Last Name field in infotype 2 as preferrred names
entry.content:
My HR clients want to use the Last name (NACHN) and First name (VORNA) fields as the chosen (preferred) names.  Alternatively, they would like to use the Known As (RUFNM) and Birth Name (NAME2) fields to track Legal Names.    

The reason for this request is because the legal names will be on an absolutely "need to know" basis.  Those who are privy to this information (security, pay, etc) will have access to the legal names via PA20 as they do now otherwise employees will only be known across the board by their preferred names.   Using these two fields as the preferred names would ultimately mean that we wouldn't have to change reports, reconfigure ENAME field, etc.

Important to note that we have an external payroll system which does not integrate with ECC,.  I'd like to know your thoughts on this solution?   I do know that the best practice is to create custom fields but I'd like to know your thoughts or opinions.  

 

Thank you!!!

entry.title: The Ultimate Guide to Banking bg software Investment
entry.content:
How do you Unlock financial solutions for your projects ! #FinancialInstruments #BusinessGrowth

 

 

The Ultimate Guide to SAP S/4HANA Transformation: Strategy, Processes, Change, and ROI

Introduction for All Users

Welcome to your comprehensive guide to understanding and navigating an SAP S/4HANA transformation. Whether you are an end-user learning a new system, a key user helping to design it, a consultant implementing it, or a manager making the business case for it, this guide is for you.

For decades, companies have relied on Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) systems to run their core operations. However, the business landscape has changed dramatically. We now operate in a globalized, hyper-connected, real-time world. The old, clunky, and siloed systems of the past are no longer sufficient.

What is SAP S/4HANA? Think of a traditional company with separate departments: finance has its own ledgers, manufacturing has its own production schedules, and sales has its own customer lists. In the past, getting these systems to talk to each other was a nightmare of custom-coded connections‚Äîa complex mess often called "interapplication spaghetti."

SAP S/4HANA is a modern, intelligent ERP system designed to eliminate this complexity. It's built on an advanced in-memory database (HANA), which makes it incredibly fast. More importantly, it acts as a single "digital core" for the entire enterprise, providing one source of truth for all data. This means that when a salesperson enters an order, the finance and manufacturing departments see it instantly. This enables real-time decision-making, streamlined processes, and a more agile, responsive business.

This guide will walk you through the entire transformation journey, from the initial strategic decision-making to modeling new business processes, managing the human side of change, and realizing a quantifiable return on investment.

Part 1: The Strategic Imperative for ERP Transformation

The decision to move to a new ERP system like SAP S/4HANA is not merely a technical upgrade; it is a fundamental business decision driven by significant external and internal pressures.

The Modern Business Landscape: From Value Chains to Value Networks

The traditional, linear concept of a "value chain"‚Äîwhere a company takes in raw materials, adds value through internal processes, and sells a finished product‚Äîis outdated. We now operate in a digital ecosystem or a "value network."

This network includes:

  • Suppliers and their suppliers: Creating deep, collaborative supply chains.
  • Partners: Co-developing products and services.
  • Customers: Who are more informed and demand personalized experiences.
  • Global Competition: Forcing companies to be more efficient and innovative.

In this environment, success depends on speed, agility, and information transparency. The ability to act locally while thinking globally is paramount. A business must be able to sense and respond to market shifts in real-time. Legacy systems, with their batch processes and data silos, create "information latency"‚Äîa delay between a business event happening and the organization being able to act on it. In the modern economy, this latency is a critical competitive disadvantage.

The Problem with Legacy Systems: "Interapplication Spaghetti"

Many established organizations run on a complex patchwork of legacy systems, packaged applications from different vendors, and homegrown solutions. Integrating these disparate systems has traditionally been a major challenge.

The common approach was to build custom point-to-point interfaces for each pair of applications that needed to communicate. For a company with dozens of applications, the result is a staggering mess of connections, aptly named "interapplication spaghetti."

This architecture is characterized by:

  • High Cost: Gartner Group estimated that up to 30% of the cost of implementing a major application was spent on building these interfaces, with even more spent on their ongoing maintenance.
  • Brittleness: The integration is fragile. When one application is upgraded or replaced, dozens of custom interfaces can break, requiring extensive and costly rework.
  • Data Inconsistency: With data being copied and moved between systems, it is often out-of-sync and out-of-date across the enterprise. There is no single source of truth.
  • Lack of Agility: The complexity makes it incredibly slow, expensive, and risky to introduce new applications or change business processes.

The "zero-latency enterprise" is the goal: moving information from application to application with near-zero delay to streamline business processes, reduce costs, and respond instantly to market demands. Interapplication spaghetti makes this impossible. SAP S/4HANA, with its integrated digital core, is the architectural solution to this problem.

Building the Business Case for SAP S/4HANA

While the technical and strategic benefits are clear, any major IT investment requires a solid financial justification. We can adapt the classic Return on Investment (ROI) model used for technology projects to build a compelling business case for S/4HANA.

The core of the analysis is comparing the projected costs and benefits of implementing S/4HANA against the alternative‚Äîcontinuing with the legacy landscape and building more point-to-point interfaces.

ROI Calculation Methodology

We can calculate the first-year ROI using a simple, powerful formula:

ROI=Cost of S/4HANA ImplementationFirst Year Savings‚Äã

Let's break down the components:

  1. Cost of S/4HANA Implementation: This includes all the one-time costs to get the system live.
  • Software Licenses: The license fee for the S/4HANA software.
  • Infrastructure: Costs for servers (cloud or on-premise).
  • Implementation Services: The cost of system integrators or internal project teams for installation, configuration, and data migration.
  • Training: Costs for training administrative personnel, developers, and end-users.
  • Change Management: Costs associated with communication, stakeholder management, and organizational readiness programs.
  1. First Year Savings: This is the most critical part of the calculation. It represents the cost avoidance and efficiency gains achieved by using S/4HANA.
  • First Year Savings = (A) Estimated Cost of Development without S/4HANA - (B) Actual Cost of Development with S/4HANA
    • (A) Estimated Cost of Development without S/4HANA: This is a projection of the costs your business would incur over the next year if you didn't implement S/4HANA. Experienced project managers and IT leaders must estimate the hours required for all planned projects (e.g., launching a new product, integrating a new sales channel, generating new reports) using the old, point-to-point method. This includes hours for design, custom coding, testing, and deployment.
    • (B) Actual Cost of Development with S/4HANA: This is the labor cost of the project team implementing S/4HANA. While this is a significant cost, it is an investment that creates a reusable, scalable platform.

A Hypothetical ROI Calculation Example

Category

Amount

(A) Estimated Cost of Development without S/4HANA (1 Year)

‚Ç¨5,000,000

Projected labor costs for custom interfaces, reports, etc.

 

(B) Actual Cost of Development with S/4HANA (1 Year)

‚Ç¨3,000,000

Labor costs of the S/4HANA project team

 

First Year Savings (A - B)

‚Ç¨2,000,000

Cost of S/4HANA Implementation

‚Ç¨4,000,000

Licenses, Infrastructure, Training, Change Management

 

First Year ROI (Savings / Implementation Cost)

50%

entry.title: Designer Installation: Step-by-Step Guide for SAP Data Services Client Tool üíª
entry.content:
Make sure you download Designer setup with the same version as your Data Services Job Server machine, which consequently makes the Designer certified with the CMS (BI/IPS) version.

In case you have BI/IPS application or client installed on this machine, make sure it is also certified with your Designer application, even if it is not being used as CMS Server:

  • 3322026- Can BOE/BI/IPS Platform Client Tools and Designer Client Tool coexist in the same machine? - SAP Data Services

Download Designer using the steps below:

  • Software Center - SAP for Me > SUPPORT PACKAGES & PATCHES > By Alphabetical Index (A-Z) > D > SAP DATA SERVICES > SAP DATA SERVICES 4.x > SAP DS CLIENT TOOLS 4.x > Select a compatible version and download it

NOTE: This post is using Designer Client 2025 (14.4.0.165) as screenshots reference.

INSTALLATION STEPS üöÄ

After downloading the setup, let's start the installation.

  1. Run the installer as Administrator user to avoid any problems.
  2. Make sure all the prerequisites which are Critical type are on Succeeded status and click on Next.

  3. Read and select the "I accept the License Agreement". Click on Next.



  4. Add the same valid License Key as your Data Services application server and click on Next:



    Additional content:
    1977090- Is a new license key required when upgrading to Data Services 4.2, 4.3 or 2025?

  5. Confirm the installation path and click on Next.



  6. Confirm the %DS_COMMON_DIR% directory of SAP Data Services Designer and click on Next:



  7. Select any additional language and click on Next:

  8. Select "Skip CMS", since this is the Designer Client tool installation and not the application server and click on Next:



  9. Uncheck the "Data Services Server" box and click on Next:



  10. Select "Skip Configuration", since this is your Designer client machine and the DSConfig.txt files will be under your Job Server machine. Click on Next.



  11. Start the installation. Click Next:



  12. Installation is complete. Click on Finish.



  13. Reboot machine is required. Only click on "Yes" after confirming that you can restart your machine right now.



  14. Your Designer should be accessible:

 

Additional content:

  • "The base keycode for the Data Services platform was not found or has expired. Obtain a valid keycode and use the License Manager to update your installation. (BODI-1116106)" after Designer installation / upgrade:

    Check the KBA below:
    1395080- How to install or maintain License/Product keys - SAP Data Services
  • For SAP Data Services 2025, missing ncs.dll:
    3641815 - Designer fails to launch with keycode error - SAP Data Services 2025

  • For SDK Failure when accessing Designer tool: 
    It might be compatibility between your Designer tool and the CMS Server (BI/IPS), but also bi-directionally communication between Designer <-> CMS Server.
    Make sure you can ping and telnet from Designer to the CMS Server and vice versa (CMS Server to Designer).
    In case it is compatible and telnet/ping works bi-directionally, check and apply the KBA below:

    2450650 - Logon failed to the specified system. Check system name, port number, user name, password, authentication method, and try again. Additional information: <Session: SDK failure>. - SAP Data Services
  • Designer client is slow:
    3034996- SAP Data Services Designer slow performance - SAP Data Services

 

üåüIf you have any questions or need assistance, feel free to reach out to SAP Support and search under our Knowledge Base!

üìåIf you found this helpful or interesting, I would really appreciate a 'Kudo' to let me know! Your feedback means a lot. üòä

entry.title: Re: Delivery adress of plant not taking in account
entry.content:
Hi,

To ensure the system derives the correct delivery address, the following configuration steps must be performed and verified:

1. SSCUI 105933 ‚Äì Maintain Storage Location

  • For Plant and Storage Location , maintain the delivery (ship-to) address:
  • Ensure all fields (street, postal code, city, region, and country) are completed. This configuration defines the address that the system uses as the delivery address for purchase orders.

 

2. SSCUI 102657 ‚Äì Set Warehouse Address

  • Go to SSCUI 102657 ‚Äì Set Warehouse Address.
  • For Warehouse, maintain the same delivery address as above. This ensures warehouse-related logistics documents (such as inbound/outbound deliveries) use the same physical address.

 

3. SSCUI 102125 ‚Äì Define Shipping Point

  • Go to SSCUI 102125 ‚Äì Define Shipping Point.
  • For Shipping Points, maintain the correct delivery address corresponding to the warehouse location. Consistent address data ensures proper address determination in delivery-related processes.

 

4. Manage Business Partner Master Data

  • Open the ‚ÄúManage Business Partner Master Data‚Äù app.
  • For BP, create and maintain:
    • BILL-TO address: XYZ
    • SHIP-TO address: ABC
  • Assign address types correctly and ensure roles are consistent with supplier functions. These addresses are used for communication and output (not for internal PO address determination).

 

Validate:

  1. Create a new Purchase Order.
  2. Use Plant and Storage Location.
  3. Check the Delivery Address tab ‚Äî it should now display the storage location address instead of the bill-to address.
  4. Test PO output to confirm that:
    • Delivery Address on the form corresponds to the storage location (ship-to).
    • Invoice Address corresponds to the bill-to address from the Business Partner.

Thanks and regards,

SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Mass update of Classification Class in Material Master
entry.content:
Hi,

It is possible to assign multiple materials using transaction CLMM and button "Set and Change values".  It is not the most obvious transaction to use, but it works.  I don't know if there is a limitation on the number of materials you can do at one time, but I had no issues with 250+ materials.

You need to go on the 3rd tab (Assignments) and enter the class with Create button selected, then go to the 2nd tab (Target Objects) and paste the materials with the copy clipboard button at the bottom.

CLMM can then be used again to assign correct characteristics values in a separate step after the class has been assigned.

Steve

entry.title: Business Goal percentage not calculating correctly
entry.content:
We have a pretty straight forward Bonus Plan

Business Goals - 90%

Individual Goals 10%

Under the business goal section, there could be 3 - 23 goals with weights adding up to that 90%. However it seems it is multiplying the dollar amount of the award first by the 90% section weight then again by the individual goal weight, decreasing the goals payout percentage. What we found is we have to put the Business Goal section at 100% and just have the individual goals add up to 90% to make it calculate correctly, however, visually this doesn't look like what we are asking for, (business goal 90%, Ind 10%).

If you look at the 2 screen shots to see the difference. When configured as you would assume, business goal section 90% individual 10% the total amount for business goals on a $1,100 Bonus payout should be $990, however it is again multiplying it by 90% and making it $891.  It looks correct, in that it says "Business Performance Goal Section Weight 90%" and Business Section Amount $990.00, but the total for that section is only $891? Can you explain this?

entry.title: Re: Reconciliation Accounts Payable after Advanced Foreig...
entry.content:
App "Manage Supplier Line Items" contains the information of the entry view table BSEG.

The advanced foreign currency valuation postings are only updated in the ACDOCA table - Posting in General Ledger Only and not the BSEG table.


as referenced in blog

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/advanced-foreign-currency-valuation-in-s-4hana-cloud-cloud-erp/ba-p/13562579


"Document posted through this will not be seen in Manage Supplier Line Items or Manage Customer Line Items app. But it will be seen in Display Line Items in General Ledger app."


In classical valuation it is also not the case that the valuation posting is made directly on the supplier/customer, it is made to a balance sheet adjustment account and offsetting gain/loss account. Customers for classical valuation can use the Balance Sheet/Incoming statement to review balances on customer/Supplier account with the adjustment account in same grouping.

In the advanced valuation there is no posting to the balance sheet adjustment account for the customer/Supplier rather there is posting on account itself.

Likewise you can use the App Balance Sheet/Income Statement to review balance on account.

In the app Display General Ledger Line Items you can use filter Business Transaction types to filter/distinguish sources on account. For example Business transaction type RFCV is used for Foreign currency Valuation.

entry.title: Re: Alternative Unit of Measures for different products
entry.content:
Dear Lakshmipathi,

thanks for your reply. I did the following steps:

1. Removed Meter from Stock-Specific UoM in Customizing (Extended Warehouse Management √† Master Data √† Product √† Define Unit of Measure Attributes)

2. Maintained Preferred UoM in EWM Product Master

  • For Product A, set Preferred UoM = Pieces
  • For Product B, set Preferred UoM = Meters


This setting works for Product A, where BuoM is the same as the preferred UoM. For Product B, where the preferred UoM is not equal to the BuoM, the Inbound Delivery and the Putaway Warehouse Tasks are created in BuoM and not in the preferred UoM, which set in /SCWM/MAT1. The preferred unit of measure in the material master is not taken into account in the inbound delivery or in the warehouse tasks. What could be the reason for this?

entry.title: Re: Streamline Data Migration from SAP ECC to SAP S/4HANA: Selective Data Transition with Time-Slice
entry.content:
Hello @matthiasstegmue 

Our customer is currently running SAP ECC 6.0 and planning a conversion to S/4HANA 2023 or 2025, hosted on RISE with SAP (Private Cloud ERP).

Using the S/4HANA sizing tool, the projected target HANA database size is around 2 TB, which is considered quite large  . Since the customer is not keen on starting a prerequisite and expensive archiving project, we explored the use of SAP Lean System Discovery Tool (SDT).

As shown in the attached screenshot, we have completed the Digital Blueprint phase, and the results are very promising , showing over 50% footprint reduction.

 

My question is: how should this reduction be interpreted in terms of hardware resources?

We are in the process of building the BOM for the Private Cloud ERP migration, and we need to come up with realistic sizing numbers , specifically:

  • Expected HANA memory size

  • Expected HANA disk size

Would it be correct to assume that the 50% footprint reduction directly translates into a ~1 TB target HANA database size (i.e., 50% of the original 2 TB estimate)?

Or is it not that straightforward, and the only accurate way to estimate the target HANA database size using Lean SDT is to perform a full sandbox conversion run?

Any insight or reference from those who have done this in practice would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks,

entry.title: Attachments Not Transferred from Purchase Requisition to Purchase Order in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I'm currently working on SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and I‚Äôve encountered a situation I‚Äôd like to share with the community.

When creating a purchase requisition using the ME51N application, I attach supporting documents (e.g., specifications, quotations). However, after converting the requisition into a purchase order, I notice that the attachments are not transferred to the PO.

I‚Äôd like to understand:

  • Is this the standard behavior in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud?
  • Is there a configuration or workaround that allows attachments to be automatically transferred from the requisition to the purchase order?
  • Would using SAP Document Management Service (DMS) or a scheduled job like ‚ÄúSend attachments to SAP S/4HANA Cloud‚Äù be a recommended solution?

If anyone has faced a similar scenario or implemented a solution, I‚Äôd really appreciate your insights and feedback.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Duplicate production entries 101 using BAPI VHURM_HU_POST_WE_PROD_ORDER
entry.content:
Hello experts,

We are working with a custom program that posts production confirmations using the BAPI VHURM_HU_POST_WE_PROD_ORDER, which internally calls transaction COWBHUWE to register production goods receipts in EWM, already packed in HUs (Handling Units).

We're encountering the following issue:

 

‚ùó Unexpected behavior:

In very rare cases, the system is duplicating the 101 movement for a production order. That is, it creates two separate material documents, each with a different batch number, for the same order.

üìå Observations:

  • The duplicated movements occur at exactly the same second, or at most one second apart.
  • This suggests a possible concurrency issue or race condition during execution.

‚öôÔ∏è Technical details:

  • In the it_hulist parameter (which specifies how many 101 movements should be posted), we are explicitly passing only one line.
  • Despite this, in about 2 out of every 500 production orders, a partial production receipt gets duplicated.

‚ùì Question:

Has anyone experienced this kind of duplication using the BAPI VHURM_HU_POST_WE_PROD_ORDER or in similar EWM + HU scenarios?
Do you know how we can prevent this unexpected behavior?

Any help or suggestions would be greatly appreciated.

entry.title: Re: Redraw mdk page SAP Service Asset Manager after filter
entry.content:
It all depends on what you are really trying to do.  Do you really want to define a persistent filter for the page or are you wanting just to search for the scanned value?

From reading your question it almost sounds more like search is what you want.  Otherwise you will need to also provide a way to clear the persistent filter value.  For searching, after you can the NFC tag and have the value you can just set it as the search string to have the standard search logic filter down the list as if the user had typed in the value manually.  The user can then clear the search to return to the full list using the existing search bar functions.

Here is an example of setting the search value from a rule.

// Set the serach value to the scan value
let sectionTable = context.getPageProxy().getControl('SectionedTable');
sectionTable.searchString = scanVal;

entry.title: RAP Fiori Elements List Report Object Page HTML Control Cache Problem
entry.content:
Hi;

We have a RAP application consist of a list report and an object page with details and items sections. We extend the object page in BAS and added a custom section to the top of the object page. Later we added a sap.ui.core.HTML control to show a specific HTML content. Everything works fine. But when we click the navigation button on every line in the list report it adds the clicked HTML content on top of old HTML content. The HTML control does not clear the old content. I think it has a cache problem. We do some research and made some minor developments in BAS but no change. How can we clear the HTML control content right after we click the navigation button? Can you help us on this issue.?

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model: What‚Äôs New as of 2025-10-06?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community members,

Welcome to the latest update from the SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud (SAP PaPM Cloud) Standard Model What‚Äôs New series! This update brings a fresh set of powerful features and usability enhancements designed to make everyday tasks faster, smarter, and more intuitive.

We‚Äôve introduced conversation history for Joule, giving you a smoother and more personalized experience with improved intelligent assistance. In Content Management, environment locking during import now helps ensure safer and more consistent data handling. We‚Äôve also made a few refinements in Modeling Settings to further enhance performance and usability. Finally, to make guidance easier to access, embedded help via SAP Companion is now available right where you need it.

Let‚Äôs take a closer look at what‚Äôs new and how these updates can make your SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model experience even better.

Report Management | Joule

Great news! You no longer have to worry about losing past conversations. In the Joule panel header, you'll now find a new hamburger menu icon that opens the History sidebar. All your conversations are stored here and are easily accessible.

Regardless of which environment you are in, you will see all your past conversations in the Joule History panel. This allows you to continue your previous conversation in a new environment, ask about content from that environment, and compare it to the previous one. The conversations are private, which means they are visible only to you.

The title for each conversation in the sidebar is generated automatically. Joule utilizes your first message to create a concise and clear title, making it easy to identify the topic of the chat.

Conversations are arranged chronologically, with the most recent ones appearing at the top. The currently active chat is visually highlighted, so you always know where you are.

A new button + New Conversation has been added to the top of the Joule History panel, allowing users to create new chats. You can still use the existing button in the main Joule header as well‚Äîboth options provide a clean and fresh chat window.

Joule's responses have improved. After each reply, you'll see ‚Äúquick replies‚Äù options, shortcuts that let you continue the conversation without typing long follow-up questions. This speeds up interactions and makes them more intuitive.

Note: Quick replies are available only with the "gpt-4o" AI model, since the "anthropic-claude-3.5-sonnet" model doesn't support follow-up messages.

Another small but important update ‚Äì the Joule icon has been moved to the header. It's now always visible, even when the Properties panel is open, making it easier to switch between panels.

 

Administration | Content Management

In one of our previous What‚Äôs New updates, we introduced environment locking  during imports in SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model to prevent conflicts and ensure data integrity. Building on that, we‚Äôve now enhanced this functionality when using the ‚ÄúOverwrite Environment‚Äù option in Content Management, making it even more robust.

Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs new in this update:

  • When the user starts an import with "Overwrite" option, the system now locks the environment until the process completes.
  • If the user tries to access Data Management, Process Management, Report Management, or Visualize screen while import is running, they‚Äôll see a message: ‚ÄúEnvironment import in progress.‚Äù

To show you how this enhancement works, there are two ways this happens.

  • User A is currently in the Modeling screen and making some changes, then User B starts importing the environment that User A is currently working on.
    User A tries to:
    • Access the Data Management screen or the Show screen.
    • Save changes.
    • Navigate to the Process Management or Report Management application.

      The system displays the message below:
  • User A is currently importing the environment with the ‚ÄúOverwrite Environment‚Äù option set to ‚ÄúYes‚Äù.
    User B wants to access the following applications:
    • Modeling application
    • Process Management application from the Environment application
    • Report Management application from the Environment application

      The system displays the same message:

 

Administration | Settings

Modeling Settings: Customize RFA Template

Previously, we have released a blogpost introducing the SAP PAPM Cloud Standard Model - RFA's field customization feature which initially supported only the following two Remote Function Adapter (RFA) types: Finance General Ledger and Finance General Ledger Items. As of today, we are glad to inform you that SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model now also supports the creation of custom mapping fields for additional RFA types such as:

  • Finance Accounts Payable
  • Finance Accounts Payable Items
  • Finance Accounts Receivable
  • Finance Accounts Receivable Items

For more details, visit Modeling Settings on Help Portal.

 

Introducing In-App Help via SAP Companion

We‚Äôre excited to introduce the embedded help content to the SAP Profitability and Performance Management (SAP PaPM) Cloud Standard Model powered by SAP Companion.

SAP Companion brings powerful contextual assistance directly into your workflow. You can access key information about the application without needing to switch to external documentation. For more detailed information and step-by-step procedures, the SAP Help Portal remains the primary source.

So far, SAP Companion support has been rolled out for the following applications:

  • Environments
  • Modeling
  • Process Management

Other applications will be supported soon, further expanding in-app support across the platform.

To learn more about different functionalities of the abovementioned applications while inside the app itself, here‚Äôs what you need to do:

  1. Navigate to any of the supported apps, for example, Modeling.
  2. Choose the "?" icon in the top-right corner of the header toolbar.
    This action opens the in-app help overlay on the right-hand side of the screen.

  3. Use the search bar inside the in-app help panel to quickly search for help topics or explore them in the list.
  4. When you hover over a specific help topic from the list, the system points you to the UI element for which the help topic is created. Once you choose the topic, the system displays a more detailed description of the selected topic.

    ‚ÄÉ

    You can also do it the other way around ‚Äì choose the ‚Äú?‚Äù icon next to a UI element to open the detailed help topic that describes it.

    ‚ÄÉ

Note:
‚Ä¢ SAP PaPM Standard Model currently does not include guided tours. For now, we offer static help and searchable documentation within supported applications.
‚Ä¢ Currently, in-app help is available only in the English language.

That's it for this update! 

We hope these new features and enhancements make your experience with SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model even better. To catch up on earlier releases, visit our PaPMCloudWhatsNew tag.

Stay tuned ‚Äî more exciting updates are on the way!

entry.title: Re: VA35N layout different in S4 then ECC
entry.content:
Transactions such as VA35N (List of Sales Orders) and VL71 (Output from Deliveries) have undergone layout and UI changes in S/4HANA due to the adoption of SAP Fiori and the simplified data model. These changes are part of SAP‚Äôs modernization strategy and are not easily reversible.

While you cannot fully revert to ECC-style screens, you do have some options:

Use GUI Transactions Instead of Fiori Apps. If your system supports it, you can still access classic GUI versions of transactions via SAP GUI for Windows. This may offer a more familiar layout.

Customize Screen Layouts via Personalization. You can personalize layouts using SAP GUI options (e.g., ALV grid settings) and Fiori personalization (limited but useful for field visibility and order)

Create Custom Z-Transactions - If the layout change significantly impacts business processes, you can work with your ABAP team to create custom transactions that mimic ECC behavior.

entry.title: Troubleshooting Document Grounding Pipelines
entry.content:
This article will cover an in-depth look into the Document Grounding Service. Including a deep dive into its MS Sharepoint Integration and a collection of issues we usually encounter with the setup routine of pipelines for Document Grounding in Joule.

The scenario: We have implemented Joule and want to enable it to consume company specific knowledge documents. In that process we follow the documentation assets to setup Document Grounding. In this sequence, we face difficulties or unclarities. This blog post should be a starting point to understand different troubleshooting vectors to successfully register a  Sharepoint with Document Grounding.

 

 

Step 1: Validate access to the Document Grounding API:

Once the service instance is successfully set up following the official documentation, the next step is to use the Document Grounding API to create a pipeline‚Äîtypically targeting a source like SharePoint. This setup process remains largely manual and can be cumbersome.

The service keys provided by BTP include an X.509 certificate and key, embedded within a JSON structure. These must be manually extracted and saved as separate .crt and .key files.

Here‚Äôs how to troubleshoot this step-by-step:

Check 1: Can you obtain a token for the Document Grounding API:

Before interacting with the Document Grounding API, verify that you have the correct url, client_id, and the required certificates. These credentials are essential for authenticating against the API.

Start by performing a POST request to the authorization endpoint to obtain a bearer token. This step confirms that your setup is valid and that the API is reachable.

Here‚Äôs what the response should look like:

Subsequently you would use the bearer token in the next request to the URL of the Document Grounding Service.

Typical symptoms that might occur are 4xx errors on the very first "Get Token" request you try. If you are not able to retrieve the bearer token - that most likely means there is an issue with the way you formulated the request. Ensure that your API client (recommendation here is Bruno) is passing the needed details correctly.

Points to watch out: 

  1. URL
  2. Client ID
  3. Client Certificate including the proper wildcard - needs to match the URL

If these three points are good, you will be able to obtain the bearer token. Let's go through some possible issues:

Symptom 1:  "401 invalid_client - Client not found"

Typical issue: The client_id is missing as part of the URL params.

Symptom 2: "401 invalid_client - Bad credentials":

Typical issue: The client certificate is either missing or not the right certificate for this client id.

Symptom 3: "404 Not found":

Typical issue: The URL is incorrect. Ensure that it ends on the /oauth2/token

Symptom 4: "400 Error":

Typical issue: The URL is incorrect. Ensure that it ends on the /oauth2/token (in this example it was /oauth2/authorize - copied directly from the key instead of correcting it)

Symptom 5: "OPENSSL BAD_BASE64_DECODE":

Typical issue: The certificate or the key file is incorrectly formatted. 

 

Check 2: Are you able to access the Document Grounding Pipeline API:

Given the bearer token, now it is time to try accessing the Document Grounding pipeline API. Typically you would do that in order to create the pipeline. Since usually the next request already would be the pipeline creation - and we might have two hard to distinguish error categories here - I recommend to try the simplest GET request the Grounding API has. 

So execute a GET on /pipelines to double check if you do get a valid response from the API. You want to retrieve a 200 OK response code and a body with a most likely empty list of pipelines.

 

This way you can be sure that in general you talk to the API correctly. If you are prompted with errors in that step - then you need to double check the following points:

  1. URL
  2. Client ID
  3. Bearer Token in "Authorization" header needs to be there and valid (it expires after x hours)
  4. Client Certificate in place with proper wildcard for this URL as well

If you do not get a 200 response - most likely you are again doing something wrong in the formulation of the request to the API:

Symptom 1: "401 Unauthorized. Ensure you have proper token and subscription"

Typical Issue: The request is missing a proper bearer token - or it is invalid by now.

Symptom 2: "404 Not found"

Typical Issue: The URL is wrong.

 

Now that you can be sure that you are indeed able to talk to the API of Document Grounding - we can come to the next challenge:

 

Step 2: Validate SharePoint Credentials:

The most frequent issue we encounter when customers set up Document Grounding for SharePoint is misconfigured API credentials for the Microsoft Graph SharePoint API. While the process may seem intuitive, it often leads to errors.

In many organizations, Microsoft administration is handled by dedicated departments. As a result, teams rarely receive the correct credentials with the necessary privileges on the first attempt. Adjusting these credentials typically involves lengthy and bureaucratic procedures.

Let‚Äôs quickly review what can go wrong:

Symptom 1: "401 External system returned an unexpected response"

Typical Issue: The credentials to the MS Graph API you maintained in the Destination do not have access to the respective API on Microsoft end to access the SharePoint sites documents.

Deep Dive Investigating Access Issues on Microsoft Entra side:

Now for this specific symptom we need to deep dive. The reason is - from the document grounding service - we get this generic 401 error message. But this is usually no big help to figure out what exactly is wrong with the credentials. There can be several possible reasons:

  1. Invalid Client ID / Client Secret values - could be a simple typo
  2. URL's - the SharePoint site URL, as well as the token service URL could be wrong
  3. Missing permissions in general
  4. Missing permission on that specific SharePoint site

So let's dive into it step by step.

The first thing I highly recommend is to use the App registration in combination with the Site.selected permission set. In the official document grounding API we also offer the possibility to use a "Oauth2Password" flow - but in general talking to many customers and Microsoft admins - the clear preference from a data governance and technical perspective is for sure the App registration. There are several reasons for this: One for example is the ability to restrict the access to only the needed SharePoint sites. The second one are organizational policies. Some orgs require multi factor authentication for the user flow and this is something clearly not possible for a technical service. You can work around it with Ip allow listing - but this is quite cumbersome and error-prone.

That being said - we will concentrate on the recommended way of using "Oauth2ClientCredentials".

How to check the SharePoint credentials and get detailed error messages:

SAP provides a specific note on "How to test the SharePoint API accessibility" https://me.sap.com/notes/3623622/E this note contains a number of cURL requests that can be used to validate what exactly is coming back from the MS Graph API. My clear recommendation here is: Use the requests given here (import them to Bruno) and get clarity on the exact error message. That way you will be able to much better narrow down what needs to be configured on Entra side.

The connection check to SharePoint consists of two steps: Obtaining a bearer token and then accessing the sites contents.

Check 1: Obtain the Microsoft Login Token:

 

Possible symptoms that might occur when you are executing this request:

Symptom 1: Invalid Request scope is missing

Typical Issue: The scope header is missing

Symptom 2: Tenant Identifier is invalid

Typical Issue: You are not using the right tenant ID for your Microsoft Entra tenant.

Symptom 3: App Registration / Client ID not found

Typical Issue: You are using the wrong identifier for your app registration. Ensure to take the (client id) from your app registration.

Symptom 4: Invalid Secret provided

Typical Issue: The secret value you 

 

Check 2: Access the MS Graph SharePoint API with the token:

Now that we can be sure, that the MS App Registration Credentials are in fact valid, we can check if the also have the permissions for that particular sharepoint:

Utilize the "Connect to Sharepoint" request from the Note. The expected response should look like this:

It should give you some details about your site and return with a 200 OK.

Now lets have a look at possible symptoms of permission errors:

Symptom 1: "401 InvalidAuthenticationToken":

Typical Issue: This is just an issue with having an invalid token copied from the first request / or invalidated by time.

 

Symptom 2: "404 Not found":

Typical Issue: This is referring to the part of the URL where you need to input the hostname and the sitename. Ensure that you are using the actual site name and not just some sort of description. Best is to take it directly from the Site URL you also open in the browser.

 

Symptom 3: "401 General Exception":

Typical Issue: This indicates a general issue with the permission to the sharepoint site api - your app registration is most likely missing the sites selected permission or it is not fully granted.

 

In MS Entra this should look like this:

On the App registrations API permission page - you need to ensure to have the Microsoft Graph "Sites.Selected" Permission added - and Status needs to be "Granted for xxx".

Symptom 4: "403 Forbidden Access Denied":

Typical Issue: In case of a 403 Access Denied on the other hand side - it is and indication that again the permissions are the issue - but in this case specifically the link between your app registration and the sharepoint site is missing. Meaning you might have the sites selected application permission granted - but as the name suggests this permission works in the combination with an additional step to setup the link between that app registration and the sharepoint site. 

How to validate Sharepoint Permissions in MS Entra:

This one is a bit harder to validate - because there is no UI in Entra. Instead the admin has the option to either use a PowerShell command to grant this:

Grant-PnPAzureADAppSitePermission -AppId <appId> -DisplayName <name> -Permissions Write

This would respond with a granted message if done correctly.

To validate one can use the following format:

Get-PnPAzureADAppSitePermission -Site https://contoso.sharepoint.com/sites/ProjectX

And again you should get the indication whether your App Registry has the permission to access that specific Sharepoint site.

Alternatively he can use a POST Request via the MS Graph Explorer:

POST https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/sites/{siteId}/permissions

The response should include you App Registry:

 

{
  "roles": [ "write" ],
  "grantedToIdentities": [
    {
      "application": {
        "id": "00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444",
        "displayName": "MY Azure AD App"
      }
    }
  ]
}

 

Similarly the GET would allow you to see which applications have access to the site. Both ways are similar.

Note: You need to perform the link between the app registration and the sharepoint site for each new site you want to replicate.

Given all these steps - we can be sure that the MS Credentials have the proper permissions for our job.

Step 3: Validate Pipeline Configuration:

Last but not least - given a working set of credentials and being able to retrieve content from the MS side - this should allow us now to create a pipeline. Below there are some additional checks to be done to ensure a proper configuration of the pipeline:

Check 1: SharePoint Site Identifier 

In the step to create the Pipeline - you are asked to provide a site name. This is a bit a tricky one - because SharePoint Sites have a title. A readable nice title -  but this is not necessarily the site identifier. Instead - the name parameter needs to be filled with the ID of the Sharepoint site. And this is best found on the URL.  For example if your Sharepoint is reachable under 

https://contoso.sharepoint.com/sites/HR%20Team

Then the site identifier would be HR%20Team

Note: Be aware of the URL encoding.

A seldom topic that might occur here is that you have a sub-site structure. This is to the best of my knowledge currently not supported by document grounding and sharepoint itself has deprecated this feature.

Check 2: SharePoint include paths

The optional parameter to limit the replication of content into the document grounding service with a include path is also something to watch out for. A typical symptom is that, after configuring an include path, no documents appear in the replication results ‚Äî indicating that the path definition is likely too restrictive or incorrectly specified.

The easiest way to validate this is by checking directly in SharePoint. In this example, I‚Äôm using the default document library, ‚ÄúShared Documents‚Äù, and have created a folder named ‚Äúteched‚Äù containing a few sample files. To determine the correct value for the include path, simply examine the document‚Äôs URL ‚Äî it reveals the folder structure that can be referenced in your pipeline configuration.

https://sap.sharepoint.com/sites/210637/Shared%20Documents/teched/Board%20Onsite%20San%20Marino.docx

Given an link roughly like this - I would now use the following path to limit the replication only to the teched folder: "/teched"

Note: We do not prepend the path with the /Shared%20Documents 

Check 3: Pipeline created but no documents

How to check - see this documentation page. It's pretty straight forward. Whenever you create a pipeline to a site - it will in a matter of  a few minutes trigger a replication job. You can then see the status of that execution and determine what is going on. Sometimes this might lead to a empty list of documents. This usually points to a issue.

If you‚Äôre not seeing any documents, you may have defined the include path too narrowly. In that case, I recommend first testing with the root path‚Äîthat is, omit the include path entirely. Once replication works, you can refine the configuration in subsequent iterations to identify which parts of your SharePoint content are being synchronized.

Keep in mind that, due to the historical evolution of SharePoint, not all structures are recognized as valid document libraries. For example, subsites are no longer supported by Document Grounding, as this feature has been deprecated in SharePoint itself. If your content resides in a subsite, the only reliable solution is to migrate it to a standard site and its associated document library.

Conclusion:

If you can answer the following questions with yes - then you succeeded in the troubleshooting

Did the pipeline get created with a 201 status code and a pipeline_id? 
Are any documents showing up for the pipeline execution? 
Does Joule answer my questions about the documents?

Hope you enjoyed the blog post and in case of any other symptoms you found - feel free to comment below.

entry.title: SFTP Sender Adapter ‚Äì How to send multiple picked files as single email with all attachments
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I have an SFTP Sender Adapter configured in SAP CPI (Integration Suite) to pick multiple files from a folder. The file names start with a specific prefix ‚Äî for example, "XYZ*" (e.g., XYZ_001.txt, XYZ_002.txt, etc.).

The current behavior:
Each file picked by the SFTP sender is processed separately and sent in individual emails through the Mail Receiver Adapter.

Expected behavior:
I want to collect all the files picked in one polling cycle and send them together in a single email, with each file attached separately in that one email.

Question:

  • How can I achieve this in CPI?

  • Is there any standard configuration or known pattern (like a Gather or Aggregator) that can be applied for this scenario?

  • If using an Aggregator/Gather step, how can we ensure all files picked in a single poll are aggregated before sending the email?

Any pointers or example iFlow design would be really helpful.

entry.title: Re: Document management, "Uploaded By" column, how to cha...
entry.content:
Hi @NicoleWu , 

The uploaded by column shall actually show exactly the information it is showing, it wouldn't make sense to change that to the owner of the document, as this owner was not the uploader.

However, I understand your requirement to also include the owner of the document to the list columns. We are working on this and plan to provide also the owner information in the Manage Documents list view in an upcoming release. 

Stay tuned üôÇ

Best regards, Sylvia Strangfeld
